title: In-Situ Cryo-EM Structural Studies of Eosinophil Granules
content: Eosinophils (EOS) play major roles during the progression of asthmatic, allergic, and other inflammatory and neoplastic disorders [1]. One of the most striking features of EOS is the abundance of cytoplasmic granules that contain four major cytotoxic cationic proteins [1]. Upon stimulation or activation, EOS migrate through the vascular endothelium, invade targeted organs, and release the cytotoxic proteins from the granules, thereby participating in tissue damage, repair, and remodeling [2]. Among the major toxic, eosinophil major basic protein 1 (EMBP-1) is present in a crystalline core [1]. Several crystal structures [3] of purified EMBP-1 have been determined. It was reported that EMBP-1â€™s toxicity is regulated by its crystallization and aggregation [4]. In allergic individuals, high levels of cytokines regulating type 2 immunity have been observed and significant focus has centered on their downstream effector cells, including EOS [5]. It is suggested that interleukin 33 (IL-33) leads to the activation of mature EOS, triggering degranulation and release of cationic proteins [5]. EOS degranulation deposits intact membrane-bound EOS granules extracellularly, and cell-free granules may also respond to the cytokines, resulting in further secretion of cationic proteins [6]. While patient and animal studies suggest a pathogenic role for IL-33 on EOS in inflammatory airway diseases [7, 8], structural understanding of such processes is lacking.
